faq.question: What is the difference between $variable / ${expression} and ?variable / ?{expression} syntax.

answer.p: Binding variables syntax varies between drivers. JDBC drivers use the following rules for properties substitution:

ul.li: $variable - inserts a value of the variable as text content.
${expression} - braces are used for JEXL expressions. For example ${column1+column2} inserts a sum of 2 columns.

?variable, ?{expression} - syntax is the same as in 2 previous examples, but the result of evaluation is set as a prepared statement parameter, thus increasing the performance and eliminating the need to escape values.
Please note that currently ?{} syntax is only supported by the JDBC drivers.

answer.p: See Reference Manual for additional details.

faq.question: How to share a mutable variable between script/query elements of an ETL file?

answer.p: In general such practice in not recommended because often it's a sign of a bad design. It's like using GOTOs or global variables in programming languages. But in several cases using a global variable may help to achieve required goal. We propose 2 approaches:

ol.li: Use etl.globals map to work with global variables. Example ${etl.globals['globalVar']}
Another approach is similar to the technique utilized in anonymous inner classes to modify a single-element array declared as a final variable.

answer.p: The following example demonstrates both approaches:
answer.source:
<etl> <connection driver="script" id="js"/> <connection url="jdbc:...." id="db"/>
<!-- Set number of records as a global variable --> <query connection-id="db"> select count(id) as c from Errors <script connection-id="js"> etl.globals['errorsCount'] = c; <script> </query>
<!-- Then reuse this variable in other parts of ETL file --> <script connection-id="js" if="etl.globals['errorsCount'] gt 0"> java.lang.System.out.println('errors count ='+etl.globals['errorsCount']); </script>
<!-- Alternatively an outer query can be used to share an array based variable between scripts --> <query connection-id="js"> var pseudoGlobalVar = []; //Declare pseudo-global variable available to nested element query.next(); //Executes child scripts <script> //Updates the variable pseudoGlobalVar[0] = 1; </script> <script> //Outputs updated value of global variable java.lang.System.out.println('pseudoGlobalVar[0]='+pseudoGlobalVar[0]); </script> </query> </etl>

You can use etl context variable ${etl.getParameter('var name')} to reference any column names. Additionally several drivers including CSV and JDBC allow referencing columns by an index, i.e. $1, $2 ... $n.
Example:
answer.source: <query connection-id="csv"> <!-- Read CSV file content --> <script connection-id="text"> <!-- Print columns, column 2,3 are referenced by name, 1,4 - by index --> $1,$secondColumn,${etl.getParameter('My Column')},$4 </script> </query>

faq.question: How to create an Oracle trigger (run a PL/SQL block)?

answer.p: To recognize Oracle PL/SQL statement blocks you'd have to specify plsql=true connection property (supported only by Scriptella Adapter for Oracle). In this case a slash(/) on a single line is used as a statement separator:
answer.source:
<connection driver="oracle" ...> plsql=true </connection> <script> CREATE OR REPLACE TRIGGER secure_del_trigger BEFORE DELETE ON emp FOR EACH ROW DECLARE unauthorized_deletion EXCEPTION; BEGIN IF <your business rule is violated> THEN RAISE unauthorized_deletion; END IF; EXCEPTION WHEN unauthorized_deletion THEN raise_application_error (-20500, 'This record cannot be deleted'); END; /
-- Other statements separated with a slash on a single line </script>

faq.question: How to control commit options and transactions?

answer.p: The following connection parameters are supported by the JDBC bridge:
answer.note:
In general avoid using autocommit.size, because in this case an ETL process cannot be rolled back correctly. Use this parameter only for performance critical operations (bulk inserts etc.).
If the autocommit is true, then setting autocommit.size has no effect.
answer.source: <connection driver="auto" url="jdbc:hsqldb:mem:test"> autocommit.size=4 <!-- Automatically commit after every 4th statement --> transaction.isolation=SERIALIZABLE <!-- Sets TX level to Serializable --> </connection>

faq.question: How to UPSERT (update or insert into a table?)

answer.p: You can leverage database-specific SQL statements like MERGE or UPSERT. See answers on StackOverflow:
An alternative approach, which is universal but is typically slower, is to use count(*) statement and do insert or update accordingly:
answer.source: <query connection-id="in"> SELECT * FROM Persons_In <query connection-id="out"> SELECT COUNT(*) as cnt FROM Person_Out WHERE Person_ID=?Person_ID <!-- If nothing found - insert --> <script if="!cnt"> INSERT INTO Person_OUT VALUES (Person_ID, Person_Name, ...); </script> <!-- Otherwise - update --> <script if="cnt"> UPDATE Person_OUT SET Person_Name=?Person_Name WHERE Person_ID = ?Person_ID; </script> </query> </query>
